questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Virtual DOM in React?
questions.correctAnswer: To optimize updates by reducing direct manipulation of the actual DOM
questions.wrongAnswer1: To replace the actual DOM completely in the browser
questions.wrongAnswer2: To serve as a database for storing React components
questions.wrongAnswer3: To handle server-side rendering exclusively
questions.explanation: The Virtual DOM is a lightweight copy of the actual DOM. React uses it to compute the minimal changes needed and applies only those changes to the real DOM, optimizing performance and responsiveness.

questions.question: How does React use the Virtual DOM to update the user interface?
questions.correctAnswer: By comparing the previous and current Virtual DOM and applying changes to the real DOM
questions.wrongAnswer1: By directly manipulating the real DOM without any intermediate steps
questions.wrongAnswer2: By refreshing the entire browser window each time an update occurs
questions.wrongAnswer3: By sending the Virtual DOM to the server for update processing
questions.explanation: React creates a new Virtual DOM with every state change, compares it with the previous Virtual DOM (a process known as diffing), and then efficiently updates only the parts of the real DOM that changed.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the diffing algorithm used by React's Virtual DOM?
questions.correctAnswer: An algorithm that compares old and new Virtual DOM trees to find the smallest set of changes
questions.wrongAnswer1: An algorithm that converts JSX directly into HTML elements on the server
questions.wrongAnswer2: An algorithm that caches entire DOM states for offline use
questions.wrongAnswer3: An algorithm that prioritizes server-side rendering over client-side updates
questions.explanation: The diffing algorithm efficiently compares the old and new Virtual DOM trees and identifies the minimum number of operations needed to update the real DOM, improving performance.

questions.question: What does JSX stand for in React?
questions.correctAnswer: JavaScript XML
questions.wrongAnswer1: Java Syntax Extension
questions.wrongAnswer2: Java Structured XML
questions.wrongAnswer3: JavaScript Simple XML
questions.explanation: JSX stands for JavaScript XML and allows writing HTML elements in JavaScript and placing them in the DOM without using functions like createElement.

questions.question: In JSX, how do you insert a JavaScript expression inside HTML tags?
questions.correctAnswer: By using curly braces {}
questions.wrongAnswer1: By using square brackets []
questions.wrongAnswer2: By using parentheses ()
questions.wrongAnswer3: By using quotation marks ""
questions.explanation: JSX allows you to insert JavaScript expressions inside HTML tags by enclosing them within curly braces {}.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about JSX syntax?
questions.correctAnswer: JSX elements must have a single parent element.
questions.wrongAnswer1: JSX allows multiple sibling elements without wrapping.
questions.wrongAnswer2: JSX expressions cannot include JavaScript variables.
questions.wrongAnswer3: JSX syntax is the same as regular HTML without any differences.
questions.explanation: In JSX, all elements must be wrapped in a single parent element. This is because JSX transpiles into JavaScript function calls that expect a single root element.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the component lifecycle in React?
questions.correctAnswer: To manage the stages from mounting to unmounting of a component
questions.wrongAnswer1: To style components with CSS
questions.wrongAnswer2: To handle user input in forms
questions.wrongAnswer3: To fetch data only once from the server
questions.explanation: The component lifecycle in React is designed to manage a component's existence from when it is first added to the DOM (mounting), updated, and eventually removed (unmounting).

questions.question: Which lifecycle method is called immediately after a component is inserted into the DOM?
questions.correctAnswer: componentDidMount
questions.wrongAnswer1: componentWillUnmount
questions.wrongAnswer2: shouldComponentUpdate
questions.wrongAnswer3: render
questions.explanation: componentDidMount is executed once the component has been mounted to the DOM, and it is often used for initializing data fetching or subscriptions.

questions.question: Why should the shouldComponentUpdate method be used carefully?
questions.correctAnswer: Because it can prevent unnecessary re-rendering and improve performance
questions.wrongAnswer1: Because it updates the state directly
questions.wrongAnswer2: Because it forces the component to unmount
questions.wrongAnswer3: Because it makes the render method asynchronous
questions.explanation: shouldComponentUpdate allows React to skip rendering when it returns false, helping to optimize performance by avoiding unnecessary updates.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of state management in React applications?
questions.correctAnswer: To handle and maintain data that affects the rendering of components
questions.wrongAnswer1: To manage the styling of React components
questions.wrongAnswer2: To optimize the network requests made by the application
questions.wrongAnswer3: To enforce strict typing in JavaScript code
questions.explanation: State management in React is focused on handling data that influences what is displayed or how components behave, allowing interactive and dynamic user interfaces.

questions.question: Which of these is a common method to manage state in a React functional component?
questions.correctAnswer: Using the useState hook
questions.wrongAnswer1: Using the componentDidMount lifecycle method
questions.wrongAnswer2: Using Redux directly in the component without any bindings
questions.wrongAnswer3: Writing inline CSS styles
questions.explanation: The useState hook allows React functional components to have and manage state, which was not possible with simple functions before hooks were introduced.

questions.question: What is a key benefit of using a state management library like Redux in larger React applications?
questions.correctAnswer: It centralizes application state allowing predictable state updates and easier debugging
questions.wrongAnswer1: It removes the need to write any React components
questions.wrongAnswer2: It automatically handles asynchronous network requests for you
questions.wrongAnswer3: It converts React applications into static websites
questions.explanation: Redux provides a single source of truth for application state, making the flow of data predictable and easier to debug, which is particularly beneficial in complex applications.

questions.question: In React, what is the primary purpose of props?
questions.correctAnswer: To pass data from a parent component to a child component
questions.wrongAnswer1: To manage the component's internal state
questions.wrongAnswer2: To handle component lifecycle methods
questions.wrongAnswer3: To create styles for components
questions.explanation: Props (short for properties) are used in React to pass data and event handlers from a parent component to its children, enabling component reusability and dynamic rendering.

questions.question: How can a React component receive data from its parent component?
questions.correctAnswer: Through props passed as attributes when using the child component
questions.wrongAnswer1: By accessing global variables inside the child component
questions.wrongAnswer2: By using local component state to fetch data
questions.wrongAnswer3: By calling the parent's methods directly inside the child
questions.explanation: A child component receives data by declaring props in its function or class and then receiving values through attributes in JSX when it is rendered by the parent component.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about modifying props inside a React component?
questions.correctAnswer: Props are read-only and should not be modified inside the component
questions.wrongAnswer1: Props can be changed directly using this.setState
questions.wrongAnswer2: Props should be mutated to update component behavior
questions.wrongAnswer3: Props and state are the same and can be used interchangeably
questions.explanation: Props are immutable within the component that receives them. To change what a component displays, state or new props from the parent must be used instead.

questions.question: In React, how do you correctly specify an event handler for a button click?
questions.correctAnswer: Use the onClick attribute with a function reference, like onClick={handleClick}
questions.wrongAnswer1: Use onclick attribute with quotes, like onclick="handleClick()"
questions.wrongAnswer2: Use the onClick attribute with a string, like onClick="handleClick"
questions.wrongAnswer3: Use onClick attribute without curly braces, like onClick=handleClick
questions.explanation: In React, event handlers are specified using camelCase attributes like onClick and the handler should be passed as a function reference inside curly braces.

questions.question: What is the difference between event handling in React and handling events in plain HTML JavaScript?
questions.correctAnswer: React uses synthetic events and camelCase event names; HTML uses native events and lowercase names
questions.wrongAnswer1: React uses lowercase event names; HTML uses camelCase event names
questions.wrongAnswer2: React automatically binds all event handlers to the component; HTML requires manual binding
questions.wrongAnswer3: React events always return a string; HTML events return objects
questions.explanation: React uses a synthetic event system that normalizes events across browsers and requires camelCase for event names, unlike native HTML events which are lowercase and have varying implementations.

questions.question: How can you pass additional arguments to an event handler in React?
questions.correctAnswer: Wrap the handler call inside an arrow function, for example, onClick={e => handleClick(e, id)}
questions.wrongAnswer1: Directly pass the arguments inside onClick like onClick={handleClick(id)}
questions.wrongAnswer2: Use onClick={handleClick.bind(id)} to pass arguments
questions.wrongAnswer3: Add the arguments in the JSX tag like <button args={id} onClick={handleClick}>
questions.explanation: To pass arguments to event handlers in React, you typically wrap the call in an arrow function so that the handler is not invoked immediately.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of React Hooks API?
questions.correctAnswer: To use state and other React features without writing a class
questions.wrongAnswer1: To create new React classes more efficiently
questions.wrongAnswer2: To improve the styling of React components
questions.wrongAnswer3: To directly manipulate the DOM elements
questions.explanation: The React Hooks API allows developers to use state and other React features like lifecycle methods in functional components without needing to write class components.

questions.question: Which Hook would you use to manage state in a functional component?
questions.correctAnswer: useState
questions.wrongAnswer1: useEffect
questions.wrongAnswer2: useContext
questions.wrongAnswer3: useReducer
questions.explanation: The useState Hook lets you add state to functional components, while useEffect handles side effects, useContext accesses context, and useReducer is an alternative to useState for complex state logic.

questions.question: Which React Hook is used to perform side effects such as fetching data or manually changing the DOM?
questions.correctAnswer: useEffect
questions.wrongAnswer1: useState
questions.wrongAnswer2: useRef
questions.wrongAnswer3: useMemo
questions.explanation: The useEffect Hook lets you perform side effects in function components, like fetching data, subscriptions, or manually manipulating the DOM after React has updated it.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the React Context API?
questions.correctAnswer: To share data globally across components without passing props manually
questions.wrongAnswer1: To manage local component state
questions.wrongAnswer2: To handle side effects in functional components
questions.wrongAnswer3: To fetch data from an API automatically
questions.explanation: The React Context API allows sharing data like themes or user information across components without manually passing props at every level.

questions.question: Which React method is used to create a context?
questions.correctAnswer: React.createContext
questions.wrongAnswer1: React.useState
questions.wrongAnswer2: React.useEffect
questions.wrongAnswer3: React.renderContext
questions.explanation: React.createContext is the method used to create a new Context object that can then be provided and consumed in components.

questions.question: How can a component consume the value from a React Context?
questions.correctAnswer: By using the useContext hook or Context.Consumer component
questions.wrongAnswer1: By using the useState hook
questions.wrongAnswer2: By passing props explicitly
questions.wrongAnswer3: By calling React.renderContext method
questions.explanation: Components can consume data from the Context either by the useContext hook or the render prop pattern with Context.Consumer component.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of React Router in React applications?
questions.correctAnswer: To enable navigation among different components or pages without refreshing the entire page
questions.wrongAnswer1: To style React components with CSS
questions.wrongAnswer2: To manage state across multiple components
questions.wrongAnswer3: To fetch data from APIs asynchronously
questions.explanation: React Router is used to handle routing in React applications, allowing for navigation between views or components without a full page reload, creating a single-page application experience.

questions.question: Which of the following components is commonly used to define routes in React Router?
questions.correctAnswer: Route
questions.wrongAnswer1: Link
questions.wrongAnswer2: Button
questions.wrongAnswer3: SwitchCase
questions.explanation: In React Router, the Route component is used to declare a route and specify which component should be rendered when the URL matches the path.

questions.question: How does the Link component in React Router differ from a regular anchor tag?
questions.correctAnswer: It prevents a full page reload and changes the browser URL to navigate within the app
questions.wrongAnswer1: It automatically styles the link with CSS
questions.wrongAnswer2: It fetches data from the server when clicked
questions.wrongAnswer3: It triggers a state reset in the React component
questions.explanation: The Link component provided by React Router changes the URL and updates the UI without causing the browser to reload the page, preserving the single-page application behavior.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Redux state in a React application?
questions.correctAnswer: To manage and centralize the application state for predictable state changes
questions.wrongAnswer1: To style React components
questions.wrongAnswer2: To handle HTTP requests
questions.wrongAnswer3: To store component instance variables
questions.explanation: Redux state provides a centralized store that holds the entire state of the application, enabling predictable state management and easier debugging.

questions.question: How does Redux ensure that state changes are predictable?
questions.correctAnswer: By using pure reducer functions that return new state objects based on actions
questions.wrongAnswer1: By allowing components to modify state directly
questions.wrongAnswer2: By storing state in local storage
questions.wrongAnswer3: By updating state asynchronously without actions
questions.explanation: Redux relies on pure reducer functions that take the previous state and an action to return a new state, ensuring immutability and predictability.

questions.question: Which Redux concept describes an object with a type property that describes the state change?
questions.correctAnswer: An action
questions.wrongAnswer1: A reducer
questions.wrongAnswer2: A selector
questions.wrongAnswer3: A middleware
questions.explanation: In Redux, an action is an object with a type property that specifies what change should happen to the state.

questions.question: What is a primary characteristic of a functional component in React?
questions.correctAnswer: It is a JavaScript function that returns JSX.
questions.wrongAnswer1: It is a class that extends React.Component.
questions.wrongAnswer2: It directly manipulates the DOM outside of React.
questions.wrongAnswer3: It requires lifecycle methods to be defined.
questions.explanation: Functional components in React are simple JavaScript functions that return JSX to describe what the UI should look like. They do not require lifecycle methods or direct DOM manipulation.

questions.question: Which React feature allows functional components to use state and lifecycle methods?
questions.correctAnswer: Hooks such as useState and useEffect.
questions.wrongAnswer1: Class components do this, not functional components.
questions.wrongAnswer2: Redux store integration only.
questions.wrongAnswer3: Direct DOM manipulation functions.
questions.explanation: React Hooks like useState and useEffect enable functional components to manage state and mimic lifecycle behavior without converting them to class components.

questions.question: When should you prefer using functional components over class components in React?
questions.correctAnswer: When you want simpler components that support Hooks for state and side effects.
questions.wrongAnswer1: When you need to use legacy lifecycle methods only available in classes.
questions.wrongAnswer2: When your component needs to access refs exclusively.
questions.wrongAnswer3: When you want to avoid using JSX in the component.
questions.explanation: Functional components are generally preferred for their simplicity and support of Hooks, which easily handle state and side effects. They help write cleaner and more maintainable code.

questions.question: What is a key feature of React class components?
questions.correctAnswer: They can hold and manage their own state internally.
questions.wrongAnswer1: They always use hooks for state management.
questions.wrongAnswer2: They cannot render JSX elements.
questions.wrongAnswer3: They are only used for styling components.
questions.explanation: React class components can hold and manage their own state internally, allowing them to track and respond to changes over time. This is one of their defining features compared to functional components without hooks.

questions.question: How do you define a class component in React?
questions.correctAnswer: By creating a class that extends React.Component and defines a render method.
questions.wrongAnswer1: By using a function that returns JSX.
questions.wrongAnswer2: By creating a plain JavaScript object with a render method.
questions.wrongAnswer3: By calling React.createComponent method with props.
questions.explanation: A React class component is defined by creating a JavaScript class that extends React.Component and implements a render method which returns JSX to display the UI.

questions.question: Which method must be implemented in a React class component?
questions.correctAnswer: render
questions.wrongAnswer1: componentDidMount
questions.wrongAnswer2: useEffect
questions.wrongAnswer3: getDerivedStateFromProps
questions.explanation: Every React class component must implement the render method, which returns the JSX to be rendered. Other lifecycle methods are optional and used for specific side effects.

questions.question: What is conditional rendering in React?
questions.correctAnswer: Rendering components or elements based on certain conditions
questions.wrongAnswer1: Loading components only once per application
questions.wrongAnswer2: Rendering the entire UI regardless of state
questions.wrongAnswer3: Automatically updating components without any condition
questions.explanation: Conditional rendering in React means showing different components or elements depending on certain conditions, typically involving the component's state or props.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common way to implement conditional rendering in React?
questions.correctAnswer: Using JavaScript if statements or ternary operators inside the render method
questions.wrongAnswer1: Using CSS to hide or show elements
questions.wrongAnswer2: Using inline HTML conditional tags
questions.wrongAnswer3: Creating separate components for every possible condition without logic
questions.explanation: In React, conditional rendering is most commonly done using JavaScript logic like if statements or ternary operators inside the render method or function component return statement.

questions.question: What will be the result of this React code? Render {isLoggedIn ? <LogoutButton /> : <LoginButton />} if isLoggedIn is true.
questions.correctAnswer: The LogoutButton component will be displayed
questions.wrongAnswer1: The LoginButton component will be displayed
questions.wrongAnswer2: Nothing will be displayed
questions.wrongAnswer3: Both LogoutButton and LoginButton will be displayed
questions.explanation: The ternary operator here renders LogoutButton when isLoggedIn is true and LoginButton otherwise, so only LogoutButton will show when isLoggedIn is true.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Error Boundaries in React?
questions.correctAnswer: To catch JavaScript errors anywhere in their child component tree
questions.wrongAnswer1: To handle form input validation errors
questions.wrongAnswer2: To optimize component rendering performance
questions.wrongAnswer3: To manage user authentication states
questions.explanation: Error Boundaries in React are components that catch JavaScript errors in their child component tree, preventing the entire app from crashing and allowing graceful error handling.

questions.question: Which lifecycle method is used in a class component to create an Error Boundary?
questions.correctAnswer: componentDidCatch
questions.wrongAnswer1: componentWillCatch
questions.wrongAnswer2: getDerivedStateFromError
questions.wrongAnswer3: componentDidMount
questions.explanation: The componentDidCatch lifecycle method is used in class components to catch errors in their children and perform side effects such as logging errors. getDerivedStateFromError is also used to update state in response to an error but componentDidCatch handles the actual error side effect.

questions.question: Can functional components act as Error Boundaries in React?
questions.correctAnswer: No, only class components can currently be Error Boundaries
questions.wrongAnswer1: Yes, with the useErrorBoundary hook
questions.wrongAnswer2: Yes, by using the useEffect hook
questions.wrongAnswer3: No, Error Boundaries are handled only by higher order components
questions.explanation: As of current React versions, only class components can implement Error Boundaries using lifecycle methods. Functional components cannot be Error Boundaries directly without third-party hooks or libraries.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of React Fragments?
questions.correctAnswer: To group a list of children without adding extra nodes to the DOM
questions.wrongAnswer1: To create reusable components with state management
questions.wrongAnswer2: To style components inline
questions.wrongAnswer3: To handle events in React components
questions.explanation: React Fragments allow grouping multiple elements without adding extra nodes to the DOM, helping keep the markup clean.

questions.question: Which syntax is NOT a valid way to use React Fragments?
questions.correctAnswer: <Fragment></Fragment> and <> </> are valid, but <FragmentGroup></FragmentGroup> is not
questions.wrongAnswer1: <> </> syntax is a shorthand for React Fragments
questions.wrongAnswer2: <Fragment></Fragment> is the standard way to use React Fragments
questions.wrongAnswer3: Fragments do not add extra nodes to the DOM
questions.explanation: React Fragments can be used with the standard <Fragment></Fragment> or shorthand <> </>, but <FragmentGroup></FragmentGroup> is not a valid syntax.

questions.question: Why might you choose to use React Fragments instead of a div element?
questions.correctAnswer: To avoid unnecessary nodes in the DOM and keep the structure minimal
questions.wrongAnswer1: Because div elements cannot contain multiple children
questions.wrongAnswer2: Because React Fragments automatically add styling to children
questions.wrongAnswer3: Because React Fragments improve component performance by caching
questions.explanation: React Fragments help avoid adding extra nodes like divs, which keeps the DOM structure cleaner and can improve rendering performance.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a Higher Order Component in React?
questions.correctAnswer: To enhance a component by wrapping it and adding additional functionality
questions.wrongAnswer1: To create multiple instances of a component in the DOM
questions.wrongAnswer2: To replace the render method of a component with a new implementation
questions.wrongAnswer3: To convert a functional component into a class component
questions.explanation: Higher Order Components are functions that take a component and return a new enhanced component, allowing for reusability of logic.

questions.question: How does a Higher Order Component differ from a regular React Component?
questions.correctAnswer: It wraps another component to add additional props or behavior without modifying the original
questions.wrongAnswer1: It renders static UI elements without any state or props
questions.wrongAnswer2: It is a built-in React method for managing lifecycle events
questions.wrongAnswer3: It directly modifies the DOM outside of React's control
questions.explanation: Higher Order Components wrap existing components to enhance or modify their behavior while keeping the original component intact.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common use case for Higher Order Components in React?
questions.correctAnswer: Sharing common behavior or logic between multiple components
questions.wrongAnswer1: Styling components directly with CSS
questions.wrongAnswer2: Managing the state of a single component only
questions.wrongAnswer3: Handling user events inside a component without reusability
questions.explanation: Higher Order Components allow developers to share logic like logging, theming, or data fetching across multiple components efficiently.

questions.question: What is the primary use of React Memo?
questions.correctAnswer: To optimize functional components by memoizing their output
questions.wrongAnswer1: To manage state in functional components
questions.wrongAnswer2: To handle side effects in React components
questions.wrongAnswer3: To create class components from functional components
questions.explanation: React Memo is used to optimize performance by memoizing the rendered output of a functional component, preventing unnecessary re-renders when props have not changed.

questions.question: How does React Memo determine whether to re-render a component?
questions.correctAnswer: It shallowly compares the component's props
questions.wrongAnswer1: It deeply compares the component's state
questions.wrongAnswer2: It tracks changes in the component's lifecycle methods
questions.wrongAnswer3: It compares the previous and next context values
questions.explanation: React Memo uses a shallow comparison of props to decide if a component should update, avoiding re-rendering if props are unchanged.

questions.question: Which of the following is a limitation of using React Memo?
questions.correctAnswer: It only works with functional components
questions.wrongAnswer1: It does not prevent re-rendering caused by state changes within the component
questions.wrongAnswer2: It requires the use of class components
questions.wrongAnswer3: It automatically optimizes all children components
questions.explanation: React Memo is designed for functional components and does not prevent re-renders caused by state changes inside the component itself. It also does not affect class components or children components automatically.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the useEffect hook in React?
questions.correctAnswer: To perform side effects in function components
questions.wrongAnswer1: To create new components dynamically
questions.wrongAnswer2: To directly modify the DOM elements
questions.wrongAnswer3: To handle form validation automatically
questions.explanation: The useEffect hook is designed to handle side effects such as data fetching, subscriptions, or manually changing the DOM in function components.

questions.question: When does the useEffect hook run if no dependency array is provided?
questions.correctAnswer: After every completed render
questions.wrongAnswer1: Only on the initial render
questions.wrongAnswer2: Only when state changes
questions.wrongAnswer3: It never runs without dependencies
questions.explanation: If the dependency array is omitted, useEffect executes its effect after every render of the component.

questions.question: What happens if you pass an empty array as the dependency to useEffect?
questions.correctAnswer: The effect runs only once after the initial render
questions.wrongAnswer1: The effect runs after every render
questions.wrongAnswer2: The effect never runs
questions.wrongAnswer3: The effect runs only when state updates
questions.explanation: Passing an empty array as the dependency means the effect will execute only once after the component's first render, similar to componentDidMount.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the useState Hook in React?
questions.correctAnswer: To add state to functional components
questions.wrongAnswer1: To fetch data from APIs
questions.wrongAnswer2: To manage component side effects
questions.wrongAnswer3: To style components dynamically
questions.explanation: The useState Hook allows functional components to have state variables, enabling them to hold and manage local state data.

questions.question: How do you correctly initialize a state variable using useState Hook in React?
questions.correctAnswer: const [count, setCount] = useState(0)
questions.wrongAnswer1: const count = useState(0)
questions.wrongAnswer2: let [count] = useState(0)
questions.wrongAnswer3: useState(count, 0)
questions.explanation: The useState Hook returns an array with two elements: the current state and a function to update it, which we typically destructure into variables.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the setter function returned by the useState Hook?
questions.correctAnswer: It schedules an update to the state variable and causes the component to re-render
questions.wrongAnswer1: It immediately changes the state variable without re-rendering
questions.wrongAnswer2: It resets the state variable to its initial value
questions.wrongAnswer3: It deletes the state variable from the component
questions.explanation: When the setter function is called, React schedules a state update and re-renders the component with the new state value.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the useContext hook in React?
questions.correctAnswer: To share data between components without passing props manually
questions.wrongAnswer1: To manage local component state
questions.wrongAnswer2: To make API requests within components
questions.wrongAnswer3: To handle component side effects
questions.explanation: The useContext hook is designed to allow components to access data from a context without the need to pass props down through every level of the component tree.

questions.question: How do you use the useContext hook in a functional component?
questions.correctAnswer: Call useContext with the Context object as an argument
questions.wrongAnswer1: Use useContext without any arguments
questions.wrongAnswer2: Use useContext only in class components
questions.wrongAnswer3: Call useContext with a string representing the context name
questions.explanation: You use the useContext hook by passing the Context object created by React.createContext as an argument, which returns the current context value.

questions.question: What must be done before using the useContext hook to access data?
questions.correctAnswer: The component must be wrapped inside a Context.Provider with a value
questions.wrongAnswer1: The component must import React from external library
questions.wrongAnswer2: The component must define a state variable with useState
questions.wrongAnswer3: The component must have a useEffect hook defined
questions.explanation: For useContext to provide a value, the component must be a descendant of a Context.Provider that supplies the context value.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of React Portals?
questions.correctAnswer: To render children into a DOM node that exists outside the parent component's DOM hierarchy
questions.wrongAnswer1: To create a new React component
questions.wrongAnswer2: To route between different pages
questions.wrongAnswer3: To manage state within a component
questions.explanation: React Portals allow rendering of children components into a different part of the DOM that is outside the usual parent-child DOM hierarchy, which is useful for modals, tooltips, and overlays.

questions.question: Which method is used to create a React Portal?
questions.correctAnswer: ReactDOM.createPortal
questions.wrongAnswer1: React.createPortal
questions.wrongAnswer2: ReactDOM.renderPortal
questions.wrongAnswer3: React.createElementPortal
questions.explanation: The ReactDOM.createPortal method is used to render children into a different DOM node outside the parent hierarchy.

questions.question: When would you typically use a React Portal?
questions.correctAnswer: When you need to render a component outside the main DOM tree, such as modals or tooltips
questions.wrongAnswer1: When you want to handle form submissions
questions.wrongAnswer2: When you want to update component state
questions.wrongAnswer3: When you want to fetch data from an API
questions.explanation: React Portals are especially useful for rendering UI elements like modals or tooltips that visually need to appear above other content and outside the main component DOM hierarchy.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of React Suspense?
questions.correctAnswer: To delay rendering until a component is ready
questions.wrongAnswer1: To speed up component rendering
questions.wrongAnswer2: To prevent user interactions
questions.wrongAnswer3: To manage component styles
questions.explanation: React Suspense allows you to delay rendering part of your component tree until some condition is met, such as data loading or code splitting, improving user experience.

questions.question: Which feature commonly works together with React Suspense for data fetching?
questions.correctAnswer: Concurrent Mode
questions.wrongAnswer1: Redux
questions.wrongAnswer2: React Router
questions.wrongAnswer3: CSS Modules
questions.explanation: React Suspense when used with Concurrent Mode can manage asynchronous rendering effectively, allowing components to wait for data before rendering.

questions.question: How does React Suspense help with code-splitting?
questions.correctAnswer: By showing a fallback UI while a lazy-loaded component is being loaded
questions.wrongAnswer1: By preloading all components at once
questions.wrongAnswer2: By blocking rendering of the entire app
questions.wrongAnswer3: By controlling the component's CSS styles dynamically
questions.explanation: React Suspense can display a fallback component while the actual component is loaded asynchronously, helping with efficient code-splitting.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of code splitting in React applications
questions.correctAnswer: To load only the necessary code for the current view, improving performance
questions.wrongAnswer1: To split the code into smaller files for easier debugging
questions.wrongAnswer2: To combine multiple scripts into one file to reduce HTTP requests
questions.wrongAnswer3: To convert class components into functional components automatically
questions.explanation: Code splitting allows a React app to load only the code required for the current page or view, which speeds up initial load time and improves performance.

questions.question: Which React API is commonly used to implement code splitting by dynamically loading components?
questions.correctAnswer: React.lazy
questions.wrongAnswer1: React.memo
questions.wrongAnswer2: React.forwardRef
questions.wrongAnswer3: React.Fragment
questions.explanation: React.lazy enables dynamic import of components, which is essential for code splitting by loading components only when needed.

questions.question: What role does Webpack play in code splitting for React projects?
questions.correctAnswer: Webpack analyzes imports and splits the code into separate chunks automatically
questions.wrongAnswer1: Webpack converts JSX into regular JavaScript code
questions.wrongAnswer2: Webpack provides default styling for React components
questions.wrongAnswer3: Webpack manages React component state efficiently
questions.explanation: Webpack is a module bundler that can split the application code into smaller chunks based on dynamic imports, facilitating code splitting in React apps.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of lazy loading in React?
questions.correctAnswer: To load components only when they are needed to improve performance
questions.wrongAnswer1: To preload all components at once to reduce load times
questions.wrongAnswer2: To load data from the server before rendering components
questions.wrongAnswer3: To cache components on the client side permanently
questions.explanation: Lazy loading in React is used to defer loading of components until they are actually needed, which helps improve initial load performance.

questions.question: Which React feature is primarily used to implement lazy loading of components?
questions.correctAnswer: React.lazy with Suspense
questions.wrongAnswer1: useEffect hook
questions.wrongAnswer2: Redux middleware
questions.wrongAnswer3: Context API
questions.explanation: React.lazy and Suspense are the primary features in React used to implement lazy loading of components, enabling dynamic import().

questions.question: How do you handle the loading state when lazy loading a component in React?
questions.correctAnswer: By wrapping the lazy component in a Suspense component and providing a fallback UI
questions.wrongAnswer1: By using a standard conditional rendering without Suspense
questions.wrongAnswer2: By using useState to track load progress manually
questions.wrongAnswer3: By preloading the component with preload attribute
questions.explanation: Suspense provides a fallback prop that defines what to display while the lazy component is being loaded, allowing handling of the loading state.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of React Fiber in React?
questions.correctAnswer: To enable incremental rendering and improve rendering performance
questions.wrongAnswer1: To provide a new syntax for writing React components
questions.wrongAnswer2: To manage state more efficiently in React applications
questions.wrongAnswer3: To replace the React context API for data sharing
questions.explanation: React Fiber is a reimplementation of the React core algorithm designed to enable incremental rendering, allowing React to pause and resume work while maintaining high responsiveness and better user experience.

questions.question: How does React Fiber improve the rendering process compared to the previous algorithm?
questions.correctAnswer: By breaking work into units and spreading it over multiple frames for smoother rendering
questions.wrongAnswer1: By rendering the entire component tree in one synchronous pass
questions.wrongAnswer2: By using more memory to store snapshots of components at each render
questions.wrongAnswer3: By compiling JSX directly into native code
questions.explanation: React Fiber breaks the rendering work into smaller units that can be spread over multiple frames, which helps in keeping the UI responsive, unlike the previous synchronous algorithm that could block the UI.

questions.question: Which feature is a key advantage introduced by React Fiber?
questions.correctAnswer: Ability to prioritize and interrupt rendering tasks
questions.wrongAnswer1: Automatic code splitting for all components
questions.wrongAnswer2: Built-in internationalization support
questions.wrongAnswer3: Direct manipulation of the DOM tree outside React's control
questions.explanation: React Fiber allows React to assign priorities to different rendering tasks and interrupt lower priority work to focus on higher priority updates, enhancing responsiveness especially in complex applications.

questions.question: What is the primary benefit of using pure components in React?
questions.correctAnswer: They help optimize rendering performance by preventing unnecessary updates
questions.wrongAnswer1: They allow using state inside functional components
questions.wrongAnswer2: They provide built-in routing for navigation
questions.wrongAnswer3: They manage the global state of the application
questions.explanation: Pure components implement shouldComponentUpdate with a shallow prop and state comparison, which helps avoid unnecessary re-renders and improves performance.

questions.question: How does a pure component determine whether to re-render or not?
questions.correctAnswer: By performing a shallow comparison of props and state
questions.wrongAnswer1: By checking if props have deeply nested changes
questions.wrongAnswer2: By always re-rendering when setState is called
questions.wrongAnswer3: By using the Context API to detect changes
questions.explanation: Pure components use shallow comparison of current and next props and state to decide if a re-render is necessary, skipping updates if nothing changed.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about React.PureComponent?
questions.correctAnswer: It automatically implements shouldComponentUpdate with shallow comparison
questions.wrongAnswer1: It disables lifecycle methods for optimization
questions.wrongAnswer2: It is only used for class components without state
questions.wrongAnswer3: It replaces the need for React.memo in functional components
questions.explanation: React.PureComponent is a base class for class components that implements shouldComponentUpdate with a shallow comparison to optimize rendering.

questions.question: What is the primary use of React Refs?
questions.correctAnswer: To access and interact with DOM elements directly
questions.wrongAnswer1: To manage component state efficiently
questions.wrongAnswer2: To handle asynchronous API calls
questions.wrongAnswer3: To style components dynamically
questions.explanation: React Refs provide a way to access DOM nodes or React elements created in the render method, enabling direct interaction with the DOM.

questions.question: Which React hook is commonly used to create refs in functional components?
questions.correctAnswer: useRef
questions.wrongAnswer1: useState
questions.wrongAnswer2: useEffect
questions.wrongAnswer3: useContext
questions.explanation: The useRef hook allows you to create a ref object that persists across renders and can be used to reference DOM elements or hold mutable values.

questions.question: How do you attach a ref to a DOM element in React?
questions.correctAnswer: By passing the ref object to the ref attribute of the element
questions.wrongAnswer1: By adding a special data-ref attribute
questions.wrongAnswer2: By including it in the props object manually
questions.wrongAnswer3: By wrapping the element in a RefContainer component
questions.explanation: Refs are attached to React elements using the ref attribute, which accepts a ref object created by React.createRef or useRef.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of React Testing?
questions.correctAnswer: To ensure React components behave as expected
questions.wrongAnswer1: To style React components
questions.wrongAnswer2: To deploy React applications
questions.wrongAnswer3: To write React components faster
questions.explanation: React Testing is primarily used to verify that React components behave as expected under different conditions and do not produce errors.

questions.question: Which library is commonly used for testing React components?
questions.correctAnswer: React Testing Library
questions.wrongAnswer1: Express
questions.wrongAnswer2: Redux
questions.wrongAnswer3: Bootstrap
questions.explanation: React Testing Library is widely used to test React components by rendering them and making assertions about their output and behavior.

questions.question: What does the React Testing Library encourage developers to do when writing tests?
questions.correctAnswer: Write tests that focus on user interactions and component output
questions.wrongAnswer1: Test implementation details of components
questions.wrongAnswer2: Only test the styling of components
questions.wrongAnswer3: Avoid testing components altogether
questions.explanation: React Testing Library advocates for writing tests that simulate how users interact with components and focus on what the components render, rather than their internal implementation details.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of React DevTools?
questions.correctAnswer: To inspect and debug React component hierarchies in a web application
questions.wrongAnswer1: To deploy React applications to production servers
questions.wrongAnswer2: To write React components in a text editor
questions.wrongAnswer3: To convert React projects into mobile applications
questions.explanation: React DevTools is a browser extension that allows developers to inspect the React component tree, observe props and state, and debug component behavior during development.

questions.question: Which feature is NOT provided by React DevTools?
questions.correctAnswer: Automatically fixing errors in React code
questions.wrongAnswer1: Inspecting the component tree
questions.wrongAnswer2: Viewing the props and state of components
questions.wrongAnswer3: Profiling component rendering performance
questions.explanation: React DevTools helps inspect component hierarchies and profile rendering, but it does not automatically fix any errors in the code.

questions.question: How can React DevTools help improve React application performance?
questions.correctAnswer: By profiling component render times to identify performance bottlenecks
questions.wrongAnswer1: By minifying the application code automatically
questions.wrongAnswer2: By generating production build files
questions.wrongAnswer3: By automatically rewriting inefficient components
questions.explanation: React DevTools includes a profiling tool that records render times for components and helps developers detect which parts of the UI need performance optimizations.

questions.question: What is React Native primarily used for?
questions.correctAnswer: Building mobile applications using JavaScript and React
questions.wrongAnswer1: Developing desktop applications only
questions.wrongAnswer2: Creating backend services with React
questions.wrongAnswer3: Converting React web apps into Python scripts
questions.explanation: React Native is a framework for building native mobile apps using JavaScript and React, enabling code reuse across iOS and Android platforms.

questions.question: Which languages are mainly used in React Native development?
questions.correctAnswer: JavaScript and JSX
questions.wrongAnswer1: Python and Java
questions.wrongAnswer2: HTML and CSS only
questions.wrongAnswer3: C++ and Swift
questions.explanation: React Native primarily uses JavaScript and JSX to create components that run as native apps on mobile devices.

questions.question: How does React Native differ from React for web development?
questions.correctAnswer: React Native targets mobile platforms and uses native components instead of web components
questions.wrongAnswer1: React Native can only be used for web development
questions.wrongAnswer2: React Native does not support component-based architecture
questions.wrongAnswer3: React Native uses only Python rather than JavaScript
questions.explanation: React Native allows building mobile apps using React's component model but uses native UI components instead of HTML elements, unlike React for web.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of React Concurrent mode?
questions.correctAnswer: To improve user experience by rendering UI updates without blocking the main thread
questions.wrongAnswer1: To allow multiple React apps to run simultaneously
questions.wrongAnswer2: To enable server-side rendering of React components
questions.wrongAnswer3: To replace the React lifecycle methods entirely
questions.explanation: React Concurrent mode allows React to interrupt rendering work to prioritize urgent updates, improving responsiveness and user experience.

questions.question: Which React feature is closely associated with React Concurrent mode?
questions.correctAnswer: Suspense for data fetching and lazy loading components
questions.wrongAnswer1: Context API for state management
questions.wrongAnswer2: React Router for navigation
questions.wrongAnswer3: Redux for global state management
questions.explanation: Suspense works with Concurrent mode to handle asynchronous data fetching and component loading gracefully.

questions.question: How does React Concurrent mode affect component rendering?
questions.correctAnswer: It allows rendering to be paused and resumed, enabling smoother updates
questions.wrongAnswer1: It forces all components to render synchronously
questions.wrongAnswer2: It disables rendering of class components
questions.wrongAnswer3: It batch processes render updates only at night
questions.explanation: Concurrent mode enables React to interrupt and continue rendering work, which helps in keeping the UI responsive.

questions.question: Why are keys important when rendering lists of components in React?
questions.correctAnswer: They help React identify which items have changed, been added, or removed
questions.wrongAnswer1: They add styling to the list components
questions.wrongAnswer2: They prevent components from re-rendering at all
questions.wrongAnswer3: They improve network speed when loading components
questions.explanation: Keys provide a unique identity to components within lists, enabling React to efficiently update and manage changes in the list without re-rendering everything.

questions.question: What is a recommended practice when choosing a key for list items in React?
questions.correctAnswer: Use a unique and stable value such as an ID from your data
questions.wrongAnswer1: Use the index of the item in the array as the key when the list can change
questions.wrongAnswer2: Use a random number as the key to ensure uniqueness
questions.wrongAnswer3: Use the same key for all items to keep them consistent
questions.explanation: Keys should be unique and stable to avoid issues with component state and rendering. Using array indexes as keys is discouraged when items may be reordered or changed.

questions.question: What could happen if you do not use keys or use non-unique keys in a React list?
questions.correctAnswer: React may incorrectly reuse elements or re-render unnecessarily, causing bugs or performance issues
questions.wrongAnswer1: Components will not render at all
questions.wrongAnswer2: React will automatically assign unique keys without any problems
questions.wrongAnswer3: The UI will appear without any styling
questions.explanation: Without unique keys, React cannot reliably distinguish components, leading to errors in rendering or unexpected behavior.

questions.question: What is the main characteristic of a controlled component in React?
questions.correctAnswer: Its value is controlled by React state and updates through event handlers
questions.wrongAnswer1: It manages its own state internally without React involvement
questions.wrongAnswer2: It requires no event handlers for value updates
questions.wrongAnswer3: It automatically synchronizes with the server database
questions.explanation: A controlled component in React has its value managed by React state and updates through event handlers like onChange, ensuring React is the single source of truth.

questions.question: Why do developers prefer using controlled components in forms within React applications?
questions.correctAnswer: Because controlled components help keep form data in React state for easy validation and submission
questions.wrongAnswer1: Because they require less code and no state management
questions.wrongAnswer2: Because they automatically submit data without user interaction
questions.wrongAnswer3: Because they allow forms to use server-side rendering only
questions.explanation: Controlled components keep the form data in the React state, allowing easier validation, conditional rendering, and handling of form submission within the React ecosystem.

questions.question: In React controlled components, what happens when you omit the onChange handler for an input element?
questions.correctAnswer: The input becomes read-only because React state does not update on user input
questions.wrongAnswer1: The input automatically updates state without needing an event handler
questions.wrongAnswer2: The component throws a runtime error due to missing onChange
questions.wrongAnswer3: The input resets its value to default after each key press
questions.explanation: Without onChange handler, the input cannot update React state, so the input's value remains fixed, making it effectively read-only.

questions.question: What is an uncontrolled component in React?
questions.correctAnswer: A component that manages its own state internally without React controlling the form data
questions.wrongAnswer1: A component with form data controlled by React state through props
questions.wrongAnswer2: A component that cannot update its state dynamically
questions.wrongAnswer3: A component that always uses Redux for state management
questions.explanation: Uncontrolled components store their own state internally and rely on the DOM to handle form data, unlike controlled components which have their form data managed by React state.

questions.question: How do you access the value of an uncontrolled component's input field?
questions.correctAnswer: By using a ref to directly access the DOM element's value
questions.wrongAnswer1: By passing an onChange event handler to update React state
questions.wrongAnswer2: By using Redux selectors to get the input value
questions.wrongAnswer3: By setting the value prop on the input element
questions.explanation: Uncontrolled components do not update React state on value change; instead, you use refs to access the current value directly from the DOM.

questions.question: Which scenario is best suited for using uncontrolled components in React?
questions.correctAnswer: When you need simple form inputs without complex validation or instant state syncing
questions.wrongAnswer1: When you need to track every input change immediately for validation
questions.wrongAnswer2: When you want centralized form data storage in Redux
questions.wrongAnswer3: When you want React to fully control form input values at all times
questions.explanation: Uncontrolled components are appropriate for simpler use cases where form data does not need to be synchronized with React state on every change, such as simple forms or third-party integrations.

questions.question: What is event pooling in React?
questions.correctAnswer: A system where React reuses synthetic events for performance optimization
questions.wrongAnswer1: A method to store events in a queue before processing
questions.wrongAnswer2: A way to pool user input events on the server
questions.wrongAnswer3: A system for managing component state updates during events
questions.explanation: Event pooling in React is a performance feature where React reuses SyntheticEvent objects. This optimization helps reduce the overhead of creating new event objects for every event trigger.

questions.question: Why does React use event pooling?
questions.correctAnswer: To improve performance by reusing event objects instead of creating new ones for each event
questions.wrongAnswer1: To ensure events are queued and executed sequentially
questions.wrongAnswer2: To share events between different components
questions.wrongAnswer3: To persist event objects for long-term storage
questions.explanation: React uses event pooling to enhance performance by reusing synthetic event objects rather than creating new event objects for every fired event, which helps reduce memory overhead.

questions.question: What should you do if you want to access a React event asynchronously?
questions.correctAnswer: Call event.persist() to remove the event from the pool and keep it around
questions.wrongAnswer1: Use setTimeout directly without any changes
questions.wrongAnswer2: Clone the event object manually on every usage
questions.wrongAnswer3: React events are always accessible asynchronously without extra steps
questions.explanation: Because React pools events, accessing event properties asynchronously requires calling event.persist() to remove the event from pooling so it won't be reused or nullified, allowing safe asynchronous access.

questions.question: What is the purpose of using Forward Refs in React?
questions.correctAnswer: To pass a ref through a component to one of its children
questions.wrongAnswer1: To manage component state more efficiently
questions.wrongAnswer2: To create higher-order components
questions.wrongAnswer3: To optimize rendering performance of components
questions.explanation: Forward Refs allow a parent component to pass a ref directly to one of its child components' DOM nodes or class instances, aiding in direct DOM manipulation or integration with external libraries.

questions.question: How do you create a component that supports forwarding refs in React?
questions.correctAnswer: By wrapping the component in React.forwardRef function
questions.wrongAnswer1: By using useRef hook inside the component
questions.wrongAnswer2: By passing ref as a regular prop to the component
questions.wrongAnswer3: By defining a class component instead of a functional one
questions.explanation: The React.forwardRef function creates a component that can accept refs passed to it, forwarding them to a child component or DOM element.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct signature of a component using forward refs?
questions.correctAnswer: React.forwardRef((props, ref) => JSX)
questions.wrongAnswer1: React.forwardRef((ref) => JSX)
questions.wrongAnswer2: React.forwardRef((props) => JSX)
questions.wrongAnswer3: React.forwardRef(() => JSX)
questions.explanation: The forwardRef function takes a render function that receives props and ref as arguments, allowing the component to forward the ref to a child component or DOM element.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the React Profiler?
questions.correctAnswer: To measure the performance of React components during rendering
questions.wrongAnswer1: To manage component state effectively
questions.wrongAnswer2: To handle routing between different views
questions.wrongAnswer3: To style components easily with CSS
questions.explanation: The React Profiler is designed to help developers measure the rendering performance of React components and identify performance bottlenecks.

questions.question: When using React Profiler, which type of information can you analyze to optimize your application?
questions.correctAnswer: Render durations and interaction times of components
questions.wrongAnswer1: The order in which components are mounted
questions.wrongAnswer2: The network requests made by components
questions.wrongAnswer3: The CSS styles applied to components
questions.explanation: React Profiler provides detailed information about how long each component takes to render and how interactions affect rendering, which helps optimize application performance.

questions.question: How do you enable the React Profiler in a React application?
questions.correctAnswer: Wrap the components inside the Profiler component provided by React
questions.wrongAnswer1: Add a profiler flag in the ReactDOM render method
questions.wrongAnswer2: Use the profiling option in component state
questions.wrongAnswer3: Install a separate React profiling library
questions.explanation: To use the React Profiler, you wrap the components you want to analyze inside the Profiler component that React provides.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the useReducer hook in React?
questions.correctAnswer: To manage complex state logic by using a reducer function
questions.wrongAnswer1: To fetch data from an API endpoint
questions.wrongAnswer2: To handle side effects within a component
questions.wrongAnswer3: To directly manipulate the DOM elements
questions.explanation: The useReducer hook is used in React to manage complex state logic by using a reducer function, which takes the current state and an action to return a new state.

questions.question: Which of these arguments does the useReducer hook in React accept?
questions.correctAnswer: A reducer function and an initial state value
questions.wrongAnswer1: A state updater function and a callback
questions.wrongAnswer2: A component and its props
questions.wrongAnswer3: An effect function and dependency array
questions.explanation: useReducer accepts two arguments: a reducer function that handles action dispatches and an initial state value to begin the state management.

questions.question: How does the useReducer hook differ from the useState hook?
questions.correctAnswer: useReducer is better for managing complex state transitions, while useState is simpler for basic state updates
questions.wrongAnswer1: useReducer fetches data asynchronously, useState does not
questions.wrongAnswer2: useReducer is used only in class components, useState is for functional components
questions.wrongAnswer3: useReducer directly modifies the state, useState creates an immutable copy
questions.explanation: useReducer is designed for more complex state logic and transitions using a reducer function, whereas useState is simpler and best for basic state updates.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of React StrictMode in a React application?
questions.correctAnswer: To highlight potential problems and unsafe lifecycle methods during development
questions.wrongAnswer1: To improve the performance of React applications in production
questions.wrongAnswer2: To automatically fix all runtime errors in the application
questions.wrongAnswer3: To add extra styling and animation features to components
questions.explanation: React StrictMode is a development tool that helps developers identify potential issues like deprecated lifecycle methods and side effects in components. It does not affect production performance or fix errors automatically.

questions.question: Which of the following behaviors does React StrictMode trigger to help identify issues?
questions.correctAnswer: It invokes certain lifecycle methods and effects twice to detect side effects
questions.wrongAnswer1: It disables all lifecycle methods except render
questions.wrongAnswer2: It rerenders the entire application every second
questions.wrongAnswer3: It automatically converts all class components to functional components
questions.explanation: React StrictMode intentionally double-invokes certain functions like lifecycle methods and effects in development mode to help detect unsafe side effects and ensure components are resilient.

questions.question: How is React StrictMode typically enabled in a React application?
questions.correctAnswer: By wrapping parts of the component tree with the StrictMode component
questions.wrongAnswer1: By setting a configuration flag in the React global settings
questions.wrongAnswer2: By importing a special hook called useStrictMode
questions.wrongAnswer3: By running the React app in a 'strict' command line mode
questions.explanation: React StrictMode is enabled by wrapping JSX elements inside the <StrictMode> component. This does not require global settings or special hooks and applies only to the components inside the wrapper.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of using render props in React?
questions.correctAnswer: To share code between components using a function as a prop
questions.wrongAnswer1: To manage global state across the application
questions.wrongAnswer2: To style components dynamically with CSS
questions.wrongAnswer3: To handle HTTP requests within components
questions.explanation: Render props is a technique in React for sharing code between components using a prop whose value is a function that returns React elements. This enables dynamic rendering logic to be shared.

questions.question: How do you typically use a render prop in a React component?
questions.correctAnswer: Pass a function as a prop that returns JSX to be rendered by the component
questions.wrongAnswer1: Use it as a hook to fetch data from an API
questions.wrongAnswer2: Use it as a style object to apply inline CSS
questions.wrongAnswer3: Import it from an external library as a default export
questions.explanation: A render prop is a function passed as a prop to a component, which the component calls to know what to render dynamically.

questions.question: Which of the following is an advantage of using render props in React?
questions.correctAnswer: They allow components to share behavior without inheritance
questions.wrongAnswer1: They automatically optimize component rendering for performance
questions.wrongAnswer2: They require less code than using functional components
questions.wrongAnswer3: They replace the need for using React hooks
questions.explanation: Render props enable sharing of logic between components without the complexities of inheritance, making code more reusable and flexible.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of React Hooks?
questions.correctAnswer: To use state and other React features without writing a class component
questions.wrongAnswer1: To create new components without JSX
questions.wrongAnswer2: To handle routing between pages
questions.wrongAnswer3: To optimize images in React projects
questions.explanation: React Hooks allow you to use state and other React features in functional components, eliminating the need to write class components.

questions.question: Which hook is used for managing state in a functional component?
questions.correctAnswer: useState
questions.wrongAnswer1: useEffect
questions.wrongAnswer2: useContext
questions.wrongAnswer3: useRef
questions.explanation: The useState hook is used to add and manage state in functional components, while others serve different purposes such as side effects or context.

questions.question: What does the useEffect hook primarily allow you to do in React?
questions.correctAnswer: Perform side effects like data fetching or subscriptions after rendering
questions.wrongAnswer1: Directly modify the DOM elements
questions.wrongAnswer2: Manage component styling dynamically
questions.wrongAnswer3: Create new React components dynamically
questions.explanation: useEffect lets you perform side effects such as fetching data or setting up subscriptions after the component renders, replacing lifecycle methods in class components.

questions.question: What is server-side rendering in React?
questions.correctAnswer: Rendering React components on the server before sending them to the client
questions.wrongAnswer1: Rendering React components only in the browser after the page loads
questions.wrongAnswer2: Using React to manage server-side databases
questions.wrongAnswer3: Running React components on a mobile device
questions.explanation: Server-side rendering in React means that React components are rendered into HTML on the server, which is then sent to the client for faster loading and better SEO.

questions.question: Which React framework is commonly used for server-side rendering?
questions.correctAnswer: Next.js
questions.wrongAnswer1: React Native
questions.wrongAnswer2: Gatsby
questions.wrongAnswer3: Create React App
questions.explanation: Next.js is a popular React framework that supports server-side rendering, allowing developers to render pages on the server before sending them to the client.

questions.question: What is one advantage of server-side rendering in React?
questions.correctAnswer: Improved initial load time and better SEO
questions.wrongAnswer1: Reduced server costs
questions.wrongAnswer2: Eliminates the need for JavaScript on the client
questions.wrongAnswer3: Simplifies backend database queries
questions.explanation: Server-side rendering improves initial load performance and benefits SEO because the fully rendered page is sent from the server rather than relying on client-side JavaScript execution.

questions.question: What is Static Generation in React?
questions.correctAnswer: A method of pre-rendering pages at build time to improve performance
questions.wrongAnswer1: Rendering pages on every request to the server
questions.wrongAnswer2: Generating pages only when a user visits them
questions.wrongAnswer3: Using client-side rendering exclusively for page content
questions.explanation: Static Generation involves building HTML pages at build time, allowing for faster load times and better performance as pages are served statically.

questions.question: Which React framework is known for utilizing Static Generation extensively?
questions.correctAnswer: Next.js
questions.wrongAnswer1: Create React App
questions.wrongAnswer2: Gatsby
questions.wrongAnswer3: React Native
questions.explanation: Next.js is a React framework that supports Static Generation for pre-rendering pages at build time.

questions.question: What is a primary benefit of using Static Generation in React applications?
questions.correctAnswer: Improved performance through pre-rendering of pages
questions.wrongAnswer1: Lower build times during development
questions.wrongAnswer2: Dynamic content updating based on user actions
questions.wrongAnswer3: Simplified state management in client-side code
questions.explanation: Static Generation improves performance by pre-rendering pages as static files, which load faster compared to server-side or client-side rendering methods.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of the hydration process in React?
questions.correctAnswer: To attach event listeners to server-rendered HTML
questions.wrongAnswer1: To generate new HTML from scratch in the browser
questions.wrongAnswer2: To convert JSX into JavaScript
questions.wrongAnswer3: To optimize CSS styling at runtime
questions.explanation: Hydration in React attaches event listeners and makes the static HTML rendered on the server interactive on the client side without re-rendering the entire HTML.

questions.question: When does the React hydration process typically occur?
questions.correctAnswer: When React initializes on the client after server-side rendering
questions.wrongAnswer1: During the initial server-side rendering only
questions.wrongAnswer2: Whenever React updates a component state
questions.wrongAnswer3: When React unmounts a component
questions.explanation: Hydration occurs on the client side after the HTML has been rendered on the server, enabling the React app to become interactive without losing the initial content.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common issue that can occur if the hydration process fails in React?
questions.correctAnswer: Mismatch between server-rendered content and client components
questions.wrongAnswer1: Improper JavaScript compilation errors
questions.wrongAnswer2: Failed CSS loading on the client
questions.wrongAnswer3: Infinite rendering loops on the server
questions.explanation: If hydration fails, React detects differences between the static server-rendered HTML and its virtual DOM, leading to warnings and potentially broken UI.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of React Bootstrap in a React application?
questions.correctAnswer: To provide pre-styled Bootstrap components as React components
questions.wrongAnswer1: To replace React with Bootstrap completely
questions.wrongAnswer2: To convert Bootstrap CSS into JavaScript functions
questions.wrongAnswer3: To create custom React components without styles
questions.explanation: React Bootstrap offers Bootstrap components built as React components, enabling developers to use Bootstrap styles and features seamlessly in React applications.

questions.question: How do you typically import components from React Bootstrap in a React project?
questions.correctAnswer: By importing specific components from react-bootstrap package
questions.wrongAnswer1: By using a global Bootstrap CSS link only
questions.wrongAnswer2: By directly importing components from Bootstrap CSS files
questions.wrongAnswer3: By importing components from the React core library
questions.explanation: React Bootstrap components are imported from the react-bootstrap package to use Bootstrap styled components as React components in your application.

questions.question: Which advantage does React Bootstrap offer over using traditional Bootstrap in React projects?
questions.correctAnswer: It provides components that manage their own state and behavior in React way
questions.wrongAnswer1: It eliminates the need for any CSS styling
questions.wrongAnswer2: It automatically updates React version for you
questions.wrongAnswer3: It converts React components to vanilla JavaScript
questions.explanation: React Bootstrap components are built to integrate with React's state and lifecycle methods, unlike traditional Bootstrap which is just HTML and CSS and requires manual integration.

questions.question: What does React portability primarily refer to?
questions.correctAnswer: The ability of React components to run across different environments and platforms
questions.wrongAnswer1: The speed at which a React application loads in a browser
questions.wrongAnswer2: The ease of styling components using CSS in React
questions.wrongAnswer3: The capability to use React only on desktop applications
questions.explanation: React portability is about the capability of React components to work seamlessly across various environments such as web browsers, mobile devices, and even desktop applications using frameworks like React Native.

questions.question: Which React feature enhances portability between web and mobile platforms?
questions.correctAnswer: React Native
questions.wrongAnswer1: React Router
questions.wrongAnswer2: Redux
questions.wrongAnswer3: React Hooks
questions.explanation: React Native is designed to enable developers to build portable applications that work on both iOS and Android platforms, increasing React's portability beyond just the web.

questions.question: Why is component-based architecture important for React's portability?
questions.correctAnswer: It allows components to be reused across different projects and platforms with minimal changes
questions.wrongAnswer1: It restricts components to only be used on web browsers
questions.wrongAnswer2: It requires components to be rewritten for each platform individually
questions.wrongAnswer3: It limits the styling options available for portable components
questions.explanation: The component-based architecture makes React highly portable because individual components can be reused and shared across different environments, reducing the need for rewriting code.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the JSX spread operator in React?
questions.correctAnswer: To pass all properties of an object as props to a component
questions.wrongAnswer1: To spread elements of an array in JSX rendering
questions.wrongAnswer2: To conditionally render components based on props
questions.wrongAnswer3: To concatenate strings inside JSX expressions
questions.explanation: The JSX spread operator (...) allows you to pass all properties of an object as props to a component, simplifying the syntax when many props are needed.

questions.question: Which of the following code snippets correctly uses the JSX spread operator?
questions.correctAnswer: <MyComponent {...props} />
questions.wrongAnswer1: <MyComponent {...props}></MyComponent>
questions.wrongAnswer2: <MyComponent spread={props} />
questions.wrongAnswer3: <MyComponent ...props />
questions.explanation: The correct syntax for spreading props is using the spread operator inside braces: {...props}, which passes all key-value pairs in props as individual props to the component.

questions.question: What will happen if you use the JSX spread operator with an object that contains a prop with the same name as a explicitly passed prop?
questions.correctAnswer: The explicitly passed prop will override the spread prop with the same name
questions.wrongAnswer1: The spread prop will override the explicitly passed prop
questions.wrongAnswer2: React will throw an error due to duplicate props
questions.wrongAnswer3: Both props will be passed and cause unpredictable behavior
questions.explanation: When using the JSX spread operator along with explicitly passed props, the explicit props take precedence if they share the same name, thus overriding the spread values.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of React Context?
questions.correctAnswer: To share data across components without passing props manually
questions.wrongAnswer1: To manage local state inside a single component
questions.wrongAnswer2: To optimize component rendering performance automatically
questions.wrongAnswer3: To handle HTTP requests in React
questions.explanation: React Context allows sharing state or data globally across a component tree without needing to pass props at every level, simplifying state management on a higher level.

questions.question: Which React hook is commonly used to consume context in functional components?
questions.correctAnswer: useContext
questions.wrongAnswer1: useEffect
questions.wrongAnswer2: useReducer
questions.wrongAnswer3: useState
questions.explanation: useContext hook makes it easy to access the nearest current value for a context object inside a function component.

questions.question: How do you provide a value to a React Context for its consumers?
questions.correctAnswer: By wrapping components with a Context Provider and setting a value prop
questions.wrongAnswer1: By passing the value as a regular prop to each child component
questions.wrongAnswer2: By using the useState hook inside each child to set the value
questions.wrongAnswer3: By importing the value from an external JSON file
questions.explanation: The Context Provider component wraps its children and uses a value prop to pass the current context data to them.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the React Router in the React ecosystem
questions.correctAnswer: To handle navigation and routing in React applications
questions.wrongAnswer1: To manage states within React components
questions.wrongAnswer2: To style React components with CSS
questions.wrongAnswer3: To optimize React's performance during rendering
questions.explanation: React Router is used to manage the navigation and URL routing in React applications, enabling single-page application functionality.

questions.question: Which of the following libraries is commonly used for state management within the React ecosystem
questions.correctAnswer: Redux
questions.wrongAnswer1: Jest
questions.wrongAnswer2: React Router
questions.wrongAnswer3: Webpack
questions.explanation: Redux is a popular state management library used with React to manage and centralize application state.

questions.question: What role does Webpack play in the React ecosystem
questions.correctAnswer: It bundles and optimizes JavaScript code and assets for web applications
questions.wrongAnswer1: It provides UI components for React applications
questions.wrongAnswer2: It manages application state with a global store
questions.wrongAnswer3: It is a testing framework for React components
questions.explanation: Webpack is a module bundler that compiles JavaScript code and assets into optimized bundles for efficient loading in the browser.

questions.question: What is a common technique to improve React application performance by avoiding unnecessary re-renders?
questions.correctAnswer: Using React.memo to memoize functional components
questions.wrongAnswer1: Always using componentDidMount lifecycle method
questions.wrongAnswer2: Using class components instead of functional components
questions.wrongAnswer3: Avoiding the use of keys in lists
questions.explanation: React.memo is a higher order component that memoizes the rendered output of a functional component, preventing unnecessary re-renders if the props have not changed, thus improving performance.

questions.question: Which React hook is primarily used to optimize performance by memoizing expensive calculations?
questions.correctAnswer: useMemo
questions.wrongAnswer1: useState
questions.wrongAnswer2: useEffect
questions.wrongAnswer3: useContext
questions.explanation: The useMemo hook returns a memoized value and recomputes the value only when one of its dependencies change, which helps avoid costly recalculations on every render.

questions.question: What is the benefit of using the key prop in lists for React performance?
questions.correctAnswer: It helps React identify which items have changed to minimize DOM updates
questions.wrongAnswer1: It changes the style of the list items automatically
questions.wrongAnswer2: It forces all list items to re-render every time the parent renders
questions.wrongAnswer3: It is used to set default values in forms
questions.explanation: Keys help React efficiently update and reorder components by giving each element a stable identity, which improves rendering performance, especially for dynamic lists.
